oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fisk University
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving depicting the barrack-type buildings of Fisk University.

Originally known as the Fisk Free Colored School, Fisk University was established in 1866 in Nashville (Tenn.) at the site of former Union Army hospital barracks. The school was named after General Clinton Bowen Fisk who arrived with Union occupying forces in Nashville in 1862. Enrollment topped 900 students in the first year and, in 1867, the school was incorporated as Fisk University.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Universities and colleges
Fisk University; Education and state

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Freedmen's Bureau
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper print of the Freedmen's Bureau in Memphis. Shows three men surrounded by African Americans waiting for assistance.

The Freedmen's Bureau was a U.S. federal government agency that aided distressed refugees of the American Civil War. The Freedmen's Bureau Bill, which created the Bureau, was initiated by President Abraham Lincoln and intended to last for one year after the end of the war. Passed on March 3, 1865, by Congress to aid former slaves through education, health care, and employment, it became later a key agency in the first years of Reconstruction aiding primarily the newly freed slaves.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Offices; Office workers; Administrative agencies; Freedmen
United States. Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Land reform; Tennessee - history

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Andrew Johnson's Reconstruction
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cartoon depicting Andrew Johnson as the deceitful Iago who betrayed Othello, portrayed here as an African American Civil War veteran. Includes scenes of a slave auction, whites attacking African Americans in Memphis and New Orleans, and "Copperhead" and "C.S.A." snakes wrapped around African American man while Andrew Johnson and others look on.

Johnson served as Governor of Tennessee and in both houses of the Tennessee General Assembly and Congress. He became President with the assassination of Lincoln and was impeached in 1868. This wood engraving first appeared in the September 1, 1866 issue of Harper's Weekly.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Presidents; Racism; Political cartoons
Johnson, Andrew, 1808-1875; African Americans - Civil rights; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General view of Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General view of a Memphis street along the river front reflects the hustle and bustle of commerce and the cotton industry as displayed in downtown along Front Street. Freedmen and their families are seen laboring and occupying the area.

This hand color wood engraving was probably cut from one of the nation's illustrated weeklies. At the outbreak of the Civil War, the three leading weeklies were Harper's Weekly, Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper, and the New York Illustrated News.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Freedmen; Race relations; Cities & towns; Business districts; Merchants; Carts & wagons; Streets; Forts & fortifications; Cotton industry; Horses; Mules; Oxen

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reconstruction Governors
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Composite of five Reconstruction Governors: George S. Houston (Alabama), A.H. Garland (Arkansas), W.L. Sharkey (Mississippi), W.G. "Parson" Brownlow (Tennessee), and William W. Holden (North Carolina). The engraving is autographed by the Governors.

Augustus H. Garland (1832-1899) was Governor of Arkansas, 1874-1876. George Smith Houston (1811-1879) was Governor of Alabama, 1874-1878. William L. Sharkey (1798-1873) was a judge from Mississippi who was appointed Provisional Governor in 1865. William W. Holden(1818-1892) was Governor of North Carolina 1865 and 1868-1871. William G. Brownlow (1805-1877) was Governor of Tennessee, 1865-1869.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Governors
Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Brownlow, William Gannaway, 1805-1877; Houston, George S. (George Smith), 1811-1879

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Howard physician on his rounds in Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Howard physician of Memphis visiting patients stricken with yellow fever communicates the dire situation that the city faced during its 1870s public health nightmare.

In 1873, Yellow Fever was carried up the Mississippi River from New Orleans to Memphis. A resurgence of the disease in 1878 caused thousands to flee the city. The Howard Association, originating in New Orleans and named after a British philanthropist and reformer, came to Memphis in 1855 during the yellow fever outbreak. The young men dispensed aid, hired doctors and nurses, and organized burials.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Yellow fever; Communicable diseases; Physicians; Sick persons
Yellow fever; Epidemics

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Former slave with mother's portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Former slave dressed in a hat, suit, and beaver mittens. He is seated and posing alongside a portrait of his mother.
In the 1860 Federal Census, Warren County reported a slave population of 2320. There were sixty-six individuals listed as free colored.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: George L. White
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George L. White engraving. It is assumed that his signature is replicated beneath his image.

George L. White is noted as the university treasurer of Fisk University, the Nashville school for freedmen, who promoted the talents of the student singers, supported the idea of a singing tour for them, and gave them the name of Jubilee Singers. Their talents, which he so deeply appreciated, helped lead Fisk University out of financial crisis, provided for the a new campus, and improved the image of emancipated African Americans across the nation.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Conductors; Engravings
White, George L.; Fisk University; African American musicians; African Americans - Music; Jubilee Singers; Choirs (Music); Spirituals (Song)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Title page of Report of Freedmen's Department of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title page of the superintendent's report of the Freedmen Department for Tennessee and Arkansas.

This report predates the formation of the Freedmen's Bureau in March 1865 and illustrates the growing problem of the Union Army in coping with the welfare of thousands of former slaves in the Mississippi Valley escaping to freedom. Colonel John Eaton, Jr., was a chaplain of the 27th Ohio Volunteers before he was asked to organize contraband camps to deal with the freedmen situation.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Freedmen

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Title page of "Sparkling Gems of Race Knowledge Worth Reading"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title page of "Sparkling Gems of Race Knowledge Worth Reading" compiled by James T. Haley.

James T. Haley's purpose in conceiving this book was to instigate a "moral revolution" within the black community. By recounting the stories of numerous, successful blacks, Haley hoped to inspire African Americans to adopt the "the qualities of thrift, order, virtue, and manliness."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Race relations
Race relations

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ida B. Wells-Barnett
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ida B. Wells shown from the shoulders up. Caption reads "Ida B. Wells Barnett, Chicago, Ill., Editor Conservator".

Ida B. Wells-Barnett was a journalist, feminist, and civil activist whose challenge of segregated public accommodations and opposition to lynching made her one of the most outstanding African-American women of the nineteenth century.

Wells, Ida B., 1862-1931

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Literary Entertainment for the Benefit of Central Tennessee College Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One page notice advertising a benefit for the Central Tennessee College Library. It includes the complete program for the evening and the names of the performers.

Central Tennessee College was founded in Nashville, Tennessee, in 1866, under the auspices of the Freedmen's Aid Society. The school began in an old Gun Factory in Nashville. By the 1870s, a house and lot were purchased on Maple Street in Nashville. The school was designed primarily as a teacher college, although students could study to enter Meharry Medical College. The tuition was $1.00 per month, and $2.00 for board. In 1883 the enrollment was 360 students.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Central Tennessee College Commencement Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One page program issued for the college commencement on May 27, 1891. The program gives a complete description of the commencement activities as well as students on the program.

Central Tennessee College was founded in Nashville, Tennessee in 1866, under the auspices of the Freedmen's Aid Society. The school began in an old Gun Factory in Nashville. By the 1870s, a house and lot were purchased on Maple Street in Nashville. The school was designed primarily as a teacher college, although students could study to enter Meharry Medical College. The tuition was $1.00 per month, and $2.00 for board. In 1883 the enrollment was 360 students.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: State Colored Teacher's Institute Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One page program for a State Teachers' Institute to be held at Fisk University. Topics for discussion as well as speakers are included on the program.

After the Freedmen's Bureau ceased to exist in 1872, many of the African American schools it had helped to support were taken over by the State. To provide further teacher training, State Teachers' Institutes or workshops were occasionally held. Despite this addition, Tennessee's African American public schools remained inadequate.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Elementary school teaching; Teaching; Teachers

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thirteenth Anniversary of the Meharry Medical College
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Card advertising the thirteenth anniversary of the creation of Meharry Medical College. The ceremony was to be held at the Masonic Threatre in Nashville.

Meharry Medical College was founded in 1876 as the Medical Department of Central Tennessee College of Nashville, under the auspices of the Freedman's Aid Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church. In 1900, Central Tennessee College became Walden University, and by 1915 the College gained a separate corporate existence from the university.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medical education; Dental education; Medical students; Universities & colleges; Laboratory schools

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Grand Concert," St. Andrew Chapel program
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One page program detailing a "Grand Concert" to be given in benefit of St. Andrew Chapel's Sunday School. Performers are listed on the program.

The AMEC grew out of the Free African Society (FAS) which Richard Allen, Absalom Jones, and others established in Philadelphia in 1787. The most significant era of denominational development occurred during the Civil War and Reconstruction. Oftentimes, with the permission of Union army officials AME clergy moved into the states of the collapsing Confederacy. By 1880 there was estimated to be 400,000 members in the Southern states.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sunday schools; Protestant churches; Concerts; Music; Entertaining

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Announcement for the annual Williamson County Teachers' Institute. The announcement lists the program and guest speakers for the program.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newell Ensley
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Early etching of Newell Houston Ensley, a Professor of Rhetoric and Science at Howard and Alcorn Universities.

Newell Houston Ensley was born in Nashville on August 23, 1852, the son of George and Clara Ensley. In June, 1878, he was graduated from Roger Williams Uniersity in Nashville and entered Newton (Mass.) Theological Seminary. He bagan teaching rhetoric, Hebrew and science at Howard University, and later transferred to Alcorn University. He died ca. 1888.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Preston Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Early etching of Preston Taylor, one of Nashville's most influential African American business and religious leaders.

After moving to Nashville in 1884, Taylor became minster of the Gay Street Christian Church. He established Greenwood Cememtery in 1888, Nashville's second oldest cemetery for blacks. Taylor helped establish the Tennessee state Agriculture and Industrial State Normal College. He is also responsible for the organization of the Natinal Colored Christian Missionary Convention.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Samuel A. McElwee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sketch of Samuel A. McElwee, influential African-American leader and politician.

One of the state's most influential African American men of the 1880s, Samuel A. McElwee had to struggle to achieve a college education and law degree, but nonetheless served his race for three terms in the Tennessee General Assembly (1882-88). After his term in office, he became a noted speaker and newspaper editor. He died in Chicago in 1914.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Josiah T. Settle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Etching of Josiah T. Settle, prominent politician and orator.

Josiah T. Settle was born in the Cumberland Mountains on September 30, 1850, the son of Josiah and Nancy Settle. He was one of the earliest students of Oberlin College in 1868. He was graduated from Howard University in 1872. Settling in Mississippi he formed a law partnership with D.T.J. Matthews. After serving a term in the Mississippi legislature, he settled in Memphis in 1885, where he was appointed assistant Attorney-General of Shelby County, Tennessee. He died in 1915.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Randall B. Vandervall
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Etching of Randall Bartholomew Vandervall, prominent Baptist minister and educator.

Randall Bartholomew Vandavall was born a slave on March 23, 1832 at Neely's Bend, near Nashville. In 1862 he was elected pastor of the "African mission" of the Spring Street Baptist Church. In 1864, he and others were instrumental in the opening of the Roger Williams University, where he served as a trustee. In 1866, he formed the Second Colored Baptist Church. . He served on the Negro Committee of the Tennessee Centenial in 1897. He died in Nashville in 1898.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rufus L. Perry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Etching of Rufus L. Perry, prominent minister and editor.

He was born a slave, the son of Lewis Perry, in Smith County, Tennessee. When he was 7 years old, his father escaped to Canada. He too escaped and later entered Kalamazoo University, where he was graduated in 1861. He was ordained the same year as pastor of the Second Baptist Chirch in Ann Arbor. In later years he served as a school superintendent, as well as editor of several newspapers. He died June 19, 1895.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John J. Irvine
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders engraving of J. J. Irvine. Engraving is part of a biographical sketch.

Farmer and machinist, Irvine was born August 3, 1852 in Clarksville, Virginia. He moved to Chattanooga in 1882, where he was employed as a stationary engineer with the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. In 1882, he was elected constable of the Fourteenth Civil District, Hamilton County, Tennessee. In 1886, he was elected Clerk of the Circuit Court of Chattanooga, Tennessee. His death date is unknown.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grand Pleasure Excursion to Nashville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside describing a pleasure excursion via train to Nashville for the benefit of the A.M.E. and M.B. churches. The cost for the round trip was $2.75. The train departed from Fayetteville, Lincoln County, and arrived in Nashville, Davidson County. The trip could accommodate about 250 people.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: I am bound for the fair at Columbia!
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside promoting the Maury County Colored Fair that was scheduled for November 8, 1883. Participants were urged to take the train from Fayetteville, Lincoln County, or Lewisburg, Marshall County, in order to get to the fair. The cost of the round trip from Fayetteville was $2.25 and from Lewisburg, $1.50. Tickets were good for three days. The general manager of the event was posted as Rev. J. F. Humphreys.

The colored fairs did not last long in Maury County, and they were not held at the same time that the white fairs were held, which was usually on Labor Day.The colored fair in Columbia took place at the College Hill School, which was built in 1881. There were frequent social interactions between African Americans in Lincoln County and Maury County. This event may have been a promotional idea developed by the railway, which had recently built some rail lines in the area.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Railroads; Broadsides

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brownsville Colored Normal School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside advertising the Brownsville Colored Normal School (Brownsville, Tenn.). The text includes a list of the Board of Managers and the subjects to be taught. It is believed to have been issued during the term of Tennessee Governor William B. Bate (1883-1887).
This school was designed to instruct potential African-American educators how to teach in the common schools of Haywood County and adjoining counties in West Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fayetteville Jubilee Singers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside advertising a performance by the Fayetteville Jubilee Singers for the benefit of African Methodist Episcopal Church in Fayetteville (Tenn.). The complete programme of the event is listed.

The name of this African American singing group was no doubt inspired by the succees of the Jubilee Singers of Fisk University (Nashville, Tenn.). The titles of the tunes performed indicate that spirituals were not the only types of numbers performed at such events.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Singers
Jubilee singers

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Original Colored Minstrels
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside advertising a performance of Harry S. Eaton's Original Colored Minstrels "for the benefit of the poor." The advertisement gives the price of admission and names H. C. Claiborne and Harry S. Eaton as managers.

This may have been one of the black vaudeville specialty companies under the management of Harry Eaton in the 1890s. Other names of the troupe were Eaton's Colored Big City Show and Harry Eaton's Colored Sports Company.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Pound Entertainment
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside advertising "a grand pound entertainment" presented by the Cumberland Presbyterian Church in an unspecified place.
After the Civil War, black members of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church petitioned to form their own presbyteries and a General Assembly of the C.P.C. was established in Nashville in 1874.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: To The Colored People
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside addressed to the black population of Lincoln County (Tenn.) by the Democratic Party regarding the presidential election of 1884. The purpose of this broadside was to convince African Americans in Lincoln County that the Democratic Party was "friends" to the black population.
The 1884 presidential election was held on November 4, 1884, resulting in a close victory by Democratic candidate Grover Cleveland, governor of New York.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Jubilee Singers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Original members of the Fisk Jubilee Singers. Photograph shows 5 male members and seven female members. The title says: "The Jubilee Singers, Original Company from Fisk University, Nashville, Tenn., 1871-1882, Eleventh Season."

The Fisk Jubilee Singers are a group of African American singers first organized in 1871. Their early repertoire centered on spirituals, but also included some Stephen Foster songs. The singers were a fundraising effort for Fisk University, a historically black university in Nashville, Tennessee. After a tour of Europe in 1873, the group earned enough money to send back to Fisk to construct the university's first-ever permanent building. The building was named Jubilee Hall, and it is still standing today.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Choirs (Music); Music ensembles
Fisk University; African American musicians; African Americans - Music; Jubilee Singers; Choirs (Music); Spirituals (Song)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James M. Henderson Anti-KKK Oath
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henderson's signed oath stating he was never a member of the Ku Klux Klan or "other disguised body of men."

The first Klan was founded in 1865 by veterans of the Confederate Army. Its purpose was to restore white supremacy in the aftermath of the American Civil War. The Klan resisted Reconstruction by intimidating "carpetbaggers", "scalawags" and freedmen. The KKK quickly adopted violent methods. The increase in murders finally resulted in a backlash among Southern elites who viewed the Klan's excesses as an excuse for federal troops to continue occupation. The organization declined from 1868 to 1870.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bonds (Negotiable instruments); Oaths
Ku Klux Klan (19th Cent.); Freedmen; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); African Americans - Crimes against; Race relations

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside entitled "A Letter of Advice: To the Grand Order--the K.K. Klan-- throughout the U. States and Territories of America." The broadside was written by Nathan Bedford Forrest.

The first Klan was founded in 1865 by veterans of the Confederate Army. Its purpose was to restore white supremacy in the aftermath of the American Civil War. The Klan resisted Reconstruction by intimidating "carpetbaggers", "scalawags" and freedmen. The KKK quickly adopted violent methods. The increase in murders finally resulted in a backlash among Southern elites who viewed the Klan's excesses as an excuse for federal troops to continue occupation. The organization declined from 1868 to 1870.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: R. J. Brunson of Pulaski, Tennessee, aged 82. He was part of the original Klan and is wearing an original robe.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Duncan Diary
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Transcription of the diary of John Duncan of the University of the South. The diary has been typed on carbon paper. The diary includes only the year 1868.

John Duncan was born in New York, and died April 7, 1872, at Jackson, Mississippi. He was the son of Alexander and Mary McFarlane Duncan. In 1868, Duncan was a trustee of the University of the South and the University of Mississippi. He named his home in Jackson, Mississippi, "Casa Mia," where he lived with his niece, Mary Jane Duncan.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Farms; Farming; Plantations; Cotton plantations; Agricultural laborers
University of Mississippi; University of the South; Freedmen

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fayetteville's First Annual Colored Agricultural and Mechanical Fair
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside advertising a three-day fair to be staged at the Fayetteville Fairgrounds beginning October 10, 1872. This was to be the first annual fair of the Tennessee Colored Agricultural and Mechanical Association to be held in Fayetteville. Officers and Directors are listed on the placard.

Founded in Tennessee around 1866, this organization's black leaders were businessmen, artisans, craftsmen and politicians. They sought to teach and solidify agricultural, crafting, and mechanical skills among freedmen. The Association also provided a political base for its leaders, given that annual fall fairs drew freedmen together and would sometimes bring in national black leaders to Tennessee. Leaders were influenced by Franklin College and would found the Tennessee Manual Labor University.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Announcements

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fanny Taliaferro Daybook
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Extract from the daybook of Fanny Taliaferro showing the contract between planters and freedmen.

Fanny Taliaferro Yancy was a schoolteacher of Brownsville, Tennessee and her daybook covers the period of the 1850s to the 1870s. Included are accounts of the Civil War, plantation life, poetry, sewing, household hints, and a smallpox outbreak.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Ride for Life
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Violent moonlit pursuit on horseback involving a hooded Ku Klux Klan member and a caped young woman firing a gun.

Albion Winegar Tourgee championed the civil rights of blacks in the Reconstruction South. He used his position as judge and his training as a writer to advance radical Reconstrucion policy and Negro rights. He supported political, legal and economic reform in the face of racial conflict and Ku Klux Klan violence. His crowning literary achievements were his two Reconstruction novels of social criticism, A Fool's Errand and Bricks Without Straw.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Of course he wants to vote the Democratic ticket!
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Political cartoon of white men holding a pistol to a black man's head at a polling station in Tennessee.

This cartoon is reflective of the poltical situation in post-Reconstuction Tennessee in which conservative Democrats reclaimed control of the General Assembly. Although without significant politcal power, Tennessee blacks would continue to vote Republican statewide in large numbers until the early 1890s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Meharry brothers, founders of the Meharry Medical College in Nashville, Tennessee.
Meharry Medical College originated in 1876 as the medical division of Central Tennessee College, an institution established by the Freedman's Aid Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Race Riots testimony by Albert Harris
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six pages of testimony by a black man named Albert Harris who witnessed the race riots that took place in Memphis (Tenn.) in May 1866. The testimony was presented to a U. S. congressional committee appointed to investigate the riots.

Racial tensions flared up in Memphis in early May 1866 as white mobs attacked the freedmen's settlements in the city. Forty-six deaths of African Americans were reported as well as two whites. Thousands of blacks fled the city in reaction to the violence.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Race Riots testimony by Lavinia Goodell
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two pages of testimony by Lavinia Goodell, a black woman whose husband was killed during the 1866 race riots in Memphis (Tenn.). The testimony was presented to a U. S. congressional committee appointed to investigate the cause of the riots.

On May 1-2, 1866, white mobs attacked the freedmen's settlements in Memphis that resulted in the deaths of forty-six African Americans and two whites. Thousands of blacks fled the city as a result of the violence.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Questions to agents of benevolent societies
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three page extract of written questions posed to leaders and teachers assoicated with various benevolent societies working for the Freedmen Department.

The questions and answers of this extract reveal a desire on the part of the Freedmen Department to present a positive picture regarding the ability of former slaves to be productive, patriotic, and capable of receiving insturction and education.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unpleasant conditions in Nashville for Northern men and freedmen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six page letter highlights conditions that the author deems unpleasant and unsafe for Northern men and freedmen in Nashville during the Reconstruction period that followed the Civil War. He is writing to an unknown addressee, who, from the context, appears to be an official of some kind. The author has been a resident for four years. He tells a tale involving the Ku Klux Klan, a biased press, unfair labor practices, threats, property damage, assaults, and murder. He recommends a military presence.

The intense period of upheaval following the Civil War required some major social reorganization to occur in Tennessee, especially in cities and towns. Population statistics reflect major gains for such areas in black and white population. Nashville had 3,945 black residents in 1860 it had 9,709 black residents in 1870. Nashville had 13,043 white residents in 1860 it had 16,149 white residents in 1870.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Freedmen; Ku Klux Klan (19th cen.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bradley, A.S.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freedman Employment Office form
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Duplicate form representing an official contract recorded in the Freedman Employment Office in Louisville, Kentucky, between an employer and a freedman. A specific period of employment is outlined, along with provisions for quarters and medicines, procedu res for lost work time, and the consequences of breaching the contract. A decorative seal featuring an eagle, shield, and the motto of the Great Seal appears before the backdrop of scenes and tools of labor below appears another motto dealing with labor.

The document reveals this office had no connection to the Freedmen's Bureau or the military. High military authorities and officials with the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands were consulted and gave authorization for the formation of the office. These authorities also offered to enforce proper contracts from this office. The Bureau and such agencies sought to oversee labor arrangements involving freed slaves in an effort to protect them and help to insure "Fair Work for Fair Wages."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Seals (Insignia); Emblem pictures
Labor contract; Freedmen; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Freedman Employment Office (Louisville, Kentucky)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Negro enlistment in Union Army
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrap of a military record denoting the first names of negro enlistments in Colored Infantry Regiments. Also mentioned are some officers with the units. The notation of Gallatin and the date of 1863 most probably is associated with the formation of the 40th Colored Infantry or a mistaken date reference to their later Gallatin service, since the 42nd was not authorized to form until 1864. The reference to the 41st Colored Infantry is puzzling, since the 41st was comprised of Pennsylvannia men.

The 40th U.S. Colored Infantry Regiment was organized in Nashville between 1863 and 1864 under the authorization of Governor Andrew Johnson. The regiment performed railroad guard duty around Nashville and Gallatin and built to five companies before being transferred to the District of East Tennessee in 1865.The 42nd was organized in Chattanooga in 1864 as an invalid regiment for garrison duty in the area. Authorization came from Adjutant General L. Thomas, who referred to the unit as a laboring regiment.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Carpetbagger
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sheet music cover and lyrics of the "comic song" called "The Carpetbagger." Cover shows a drawing of a carpetbagger with the spoils of Reconstruction in a large carpetbag. The song is dedicated to General Ben Butler.

Carpetbaggers was the term Southerners gave to Northerners who moved to the South during Reconstruction, between 1865 and 1877. They formed a coalition with freedmen (freed slaves), and scalawags (southern whites who supported Reconstruction) in the Republican Party. Together they politically controlled former Confederate states for varying periods, 1867-1877.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Music publishing industry; Music title pages
Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Rochow, A.L. von

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence from William G. Brownlow regarding endorsement of the franchise
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Governor William G. Brownlow on Governor's Office letterhead. Letter is dated September 25, 1867 and has been laminated. This letter orders the state militia to enforce the franchise.

William Gannaway Brownlow (August 29, 1805 April 29, 1877) was Governor of Tennessee from 1865 to 1869 and a Senator from Tennessee from 1869 to 1875. Serving during Reconstruction following the American Civil War, Brownlow was strongly pro-union.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Suffrage; Militias; Governors

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: George Washington Carver
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Washington Carver standing beside a train. There is a short biographical sketch of Carver on the back of the photograph.

George Washington Carver (January 1864January 5, 1943) worked in agricultural extension at the Tuskegee Institute, in Tuskegee, Alabama, teaching former slaves farming techniques for self-sufficiency. Carver's work resulted in the creation of 325 products from peanuts, more than 100 products from sweet potatoes and hundreds more from a dozen other plants native to the South. These products contributed to rural economic improvement by offering alternative crops to cotton that were beneficial
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Scientists; Biologists; Agriculture; Horticulture; Railroads
Carver, George Washington, 1864?-1943; Agriculturists; African American agriculturists; Tuskegee Institute

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freedmen extract includes diary of Memphis Colored Orphan Asylum
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pages 15 through 24 of a pamphlet containing diary entries from Mrs. S. A. Martha Canfield with regard to the Memphis Colored Orphan Asylum that she founded. Mrs. Canfield observed the efforts of Rev. I. J. Hoile with the colored schools of the city and sought to help him expand his work. With the help of the Memphis citizenry, a Board of Trustees, the Freedmen's Bureau, the military, and benevolent agencies, she set up the Asylum in the former Charleston Hotel in November of 1864.

In Canfield's 1865 report to Col. John Eaton, Jr., General Superintendent of Refugees and Freedmen, she lists 100 orphans present at the institution. The Asylum retained a matron, an assistant, a teacher, a surgeon, and servants. Destitute freedmen in need of food and clothing were not turned away from the Asylum.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Freedmen; Orphans; Orphanages; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Race relations
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Canfield, S.A. Martha
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Extracts from Documents in the Office of the General Superintendent of Refugees and Freedmen

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Harper's Weekly Memphis riot scenes
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Race relations riot that occurred in Memphis in May of 1866. The black population of Memphis had swelled from 4,000 to over 15,000 by 1865. The volatile mix of former slaves or contraband, long-time freedmen of the Beale Street area, four regiments of Colored Troops, the Irish police force, and the suffering poor clashed in South Memphis for several days with the resulting deaths of 44 blacks and two whites and the loss for blacks of 91 houses, 12 schools, and four churches. See Image 2815.

Harper's Weekly was an American political magazine published out of New York City from 1857 to 1916. Noted for its wood-engraved illustrations, the newspaper presented some startling images of the racism and violence that raged across the South during the Reconstruction period. After the Civil War, the publication advocated the Republican crusade for civil rights for freedmen.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Freedmen; Riots; Race riots; Race relations; Violence
Freedmen; Riots; Race riots; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); African Americans -- Crimes against; Race relations

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Colored Orphan Asylum
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Memphis Colored Orphan Asylum depicting the suffering faced by the black children and the destitute of Memphis.

Harper's Weekly was an American political magazine published out of New York City from 1857 to 1916. The publication was noted for its wood engravings. After the Civil War, the publication advocated the Republican crusade for civil rights for freedmen. The series of sketched portraits that are contained within this issue were probably done by artist correspondent Alfred R. Waud. He and other "special artists" were sent out by the leading weeklies to cover the war and its aftermath.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Freedmen; Orphans; Orphanages; Refugees; Abandoned children; Children; Asylums; Street children

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Black tenant agreement
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Contract between Castor Sawyer of Williamson County (Tenn.) and Freeman Green in which Sawyer agreed to furnish land to Green for cultivation while Green is obligated to give Sawyer one-third of his agricultural output.

Just prior to the Civil War tenancy constituted between one-sixth and one-fifth of farm operators in Tennessee. Tenancy increased dramatically after the war due to the reorganization of the state's agriculture so that the tenancy rate was approximately 35% in 1880 and topped 40% by the end of the century.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Landlord & tenant relations; Sharecroppers
Tenant farmers; Agriculture - Tennessee

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee pension application of ex-slave
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pension application of a former slave in Tennessee named Ben Davis. The information indicates that Davis was "given" to Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest as a personal servent during the Civil War.

Beginning in 1891, Tennessee allowed pensions to be given to veterans of the Civil War residing in the state. Proof of disability and/or indigency was required along with proof of having left the service honorably. African Americans were eligible although they had to have a statement from a white resident testifying that the applicant's "habits are good and free of dishonor."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Pensions; Slavery
Military pensions; Slavery; Forrest, Nathan Bedford, 1821-1877

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Andrew Johnson Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Communication by Andrew Johnson, military governor of Tennessee, stating his support for the adoption of a Constitutional amendment to ban slavery in the United States.

The Thirteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, officially outlawing slavery, was adopted on December 6, 1865. Despite the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863, there were still several states where slavery was actually legal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Slavery; Constitutional amendments
Johnson, Andrew, 1808-1875

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gov. William Brownlow Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from U.S. Secretary of State William Seward to Tennessee Governor William Brownlow instructing him to prevent any scheme encouraging freedmen to migrate to foreign countries.
